I use ant for my development, and have run into some difficulties because of
class compatibility issues between ant and my own code, since I am running
the junit task with fork="no.

The only reason I run the task with fork="no" is that if I change fork to
"yes", the tests take a prohibitively long time to complete.  I believe this
is because a new process is created for EACH test.  I do not see why this is
neccessary, the only reason for forking is to get rid of the ant classes
from the classpath.

So my question is, is this a correct understanding of the ant junit task,
and are there any reasons why it should not run all tests in a single
process, to increase speed?

Regards,

Magnus Torfason
